title: Laws of Offerings
shortSummary: Leviticus 7 details the regulations concerning various offerings, including the trespass offering, peace offerings, and the portions allotted to priests. It emphasizes holiness, proper handling of sacrifices, and the sacredness of the offerings to God, underscoring the importance of obedience and reverence in worship.
timeline: c. 1446 BC - The Wilderness Period after the Exodus

keyCharacters.name: Moses
keyCharacters.description: The leader and mediator who receives God's instructions and communicates the laws to Israel.

keyCharacters.name: Aaron
keyCharacters.description: The high priest, whose family receives specific portions of the offerings as a perpetual statute.

keyCharacters.name: Sons of Aaron
keyCharacters.description: The priestly family who assist in the offerings and share in the portions given by God.

definitions.definition: A sacrifice made to atone for unintentional sins or offenses against God or others, emphasizing restitution and holiness.
A voluntary sacrifice expressing thanksgiving, fellowship, or vow fulfillment, partaken by the offerer and priests.
A portion of the sacrifice lifted up and presented to the Lord, symbolizing dedication and acceptance.
A portion of the sacrifice ceremonially waved before the Lord as an act of consecration.
The sacred area within the tabernacle where priests perform their duties and consume certain offerings.

outline.heading: Law of the Trespass Offering
outline.description: Instructions for the trespass offering highlight its holiness, the proper handling of its fat and blood, and the priests' right to eat it, paralleling the sin offering to emphasize atonement.

outline.heading: Priests’ Portions from Offerings
outline.description: Details the portions of burnt and meat offerings allotted to priests, ensuring their sustenance and signifying their role in mediating worship.

outline.heading: Regulations for Peace Offerings
outline.description: Describes the types of peace offerings, the inclusion of unleavened and leavened bread, rules for eating the flesh, and prohibitions against eating offerings with uncleanness, underscoring purity and reverence.

outline.heading: Prohibitions Against Eating Fat and Blood
outline.description: God commands Israel to abstain from eating fat and blood, emphasizing holiness and obedience, with severe consequences for disobedience.

outline.heading: Priestly Portions from Peace Offerings
outline.description: Instructions for offering the breast and right shoulder as wave and heave offerings to the Lord, given to Aaron and his sons as an eternal statute.

outline.heading: Summary of Sacrificial Laws
outline.description: A concluding statement summarizing the laws of various offerings given by God to Moses on Mount Sinai for Israel’s obedience.

application: Approach God’s commands with reverence and holiness, recognizing the sacredness of worship and the need for purity in our lives.
Honor those who serve in spiritual leadership, supporting them as God has ordained through His provision.
Practice obedience in small and large matters alike, understanding that God’s laws guide us toward righteousness and fellowship with Him.
Offer thanksgiving and fellowship to God with a sincere heart, remembering that worship is both a privilege and a responsibility.

keyVerses.text: Likewise this is the law of the trespass offering: it is most holy.
keyVerses.significance: Establishes the sacred nature of the trespass offering, underscoring the holiness required in atonement.

keyVerses.text: Every male among the priests shall eat thereof: it shall be eaten in the holy place: it is most holy.
keyVerses.significance: Highlights the priests’ unique role and privilege in partaking of the offerings within the sacred space.

keyVerses.text: Speak unto the children of Israel, saying, Ye shall eat no manner of fat, of ox, or of sheep, or of goat.
keyVerses.significance: Commands Israel to abstain from eating fat, emphasizing obedience to God’s holiness standards.

keyVerses.text: For the wave breast and the heave shoulder have I taken of the children of Israel from off the sacrifices of their peace offerings, and have given them unto Aaron the priest and unto his sons by a statute for ever from among the children of Israel.
keyVerses.significance: Affirms the perpetual provision for the priesthood as ordained by God, linking worship with sustenance.
